claim: The cost of food in Canada has decreased since 1970.

supporting.text: Inflation-adjusted data from Statistics Canada shows that food prices have consistently risen since 1970, reflecting higher costs for production, transportation, and retail.

attacks.text: Inflation-adjusted data from Statistics Canada shows that food prices have consistently risen since 1970, reflecting higher costs for production, transportation, and retail.
Some food categories, such as grains and dairy, have seen price decreases due to technological advancements in agriculture.
While some categories may have decreased, the overall consumer price index for food has risen, outweighing any minor reductions.
Statistics Canada's methodology for inflation adjustment has been criticized for overestimating price increases.
Independent audits have confirmed Statistics Canada's inflation calculations as accurate and methodologically sound.

supporting.text: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) for food in Canada has increased over the decades, indicating a long-term upward trend in food costs relative to other goods and services.

attacks.text: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) for food in Canada has increased over the decades, indicating a long-term upward trend in food costs relative to other goods and services.
The CPI does not account for improvements in food quality, variety, and availability over time, which may justify higher prices.
Even with quality improvements, the CPI-adjusted food costs still reflect a real increase in the financial burden on consumers.
Wage growth and disposable income have outpaced food price increases, making food relatively more affordable despite higher nominal prices.
Wage growth has not been evenly distributed, leaving lower-income households disproportionately affected by rising food costs.

supporting.text: Global factors such as climate change, supply chain disruptions, and increased demand for food have contributed to higher food prices in Canada since 1970.

attacks.text: Global factors such as climate change, supply chain disruptions, and increased demand for food have contributed to higher food prices in Canada since 1970.
Technological advancements in agriculture have increased food production efficiency, offsetting some of the cost increases from global factors.
Government subsidies and price controls in Canada have mitigated the impact of global factors on food prices.
The benefits of technological advancements are unevenly distributed, and many staple foods have still seen significant price increases.
Subsidies and price controls often lead to market distortions and do not fully protect consumers from price increases.

supporting.text: Wage growth in Canada has not kept pace with the rise in food prices, making food relatively more expensive for consumers compared to 1970.

attacks.text: Wage growth in Canada has not kept pace with the rise in food prices, making food relatively more expensive for consumers compared to 1970.
Official inflation-adjusted data shows that food prices in Canada have decreased by 15% since 1970 when accounting for overall inflation.
The inflation-adjusted data does not account for changes in food quality and variety, which have significantly improved since 1970, potentially justifying higher prices.
While wages may not have kept pace, technological advancements in agriculture have reduced production costs, leading to lower food prices.
The reduction in production costs has been offset by increased transportation and distribution costs, which are now a larger component of food prices.

supporting.text: Government reports and economic analyses consistently highlight that food affordability has declined in Canada over the past five decades due to rising costs.

attacks.text: Government reports and economic analyses consistently highlight that food affordability has declined in Canada over the past five decades due to rising costs.
Inflation-adjusted data from Statistics Canada shows that food prices have actually decreased relative to income growth since 1970.
The methodology used by Statistics Canada has changed over time, making long-term comparisons unreliable.
While some staple foods have become more expensive, technological advancements have significantly reduced the cost of many processed foods.
Government reports may be influenced by political agendas that benefit from portraying food as less affordable.
Independent academic studies have verified the government's findings on food affordability using multiple data sources.
